A book that I requested due to the subject matter, but wasn't sure how to approach reading it. I don't typically read much non-fiction except the occasional biography or autobiography. Would I skim this due its daunting size, a TPB of 654 pages] to get a review out quickly and come back to it later and do a more thorough review? Or read it all the way through, however long it took, to get every bit of information from its pages?I read it all the way through, daunting size and non-fiction notwithstanding. It is an AMAZING story/history and so wonderfully written. It flows smoothly, exceptionally well-organized to keep the story moving and to articulate the incredible evidence for the lay-person. From the first documented case of autism, to the search for those in the past who might have been autistic but misdiagnosed, the origin of the term autism, to how mothers of autistic children were treated like it was their fault the autism occurred. The men and women who wanted to decipher autism and show that education was possible as much for the children as it was for the family and friends who loved them. There were self-made 'experts' who did more harm than good, there were the pioneers who discovered treatments and that there are degrees of autism, not just all-encompassing but gradations and levels and capacities. That the introduction of the term 'Asperger Syndrome' was an accident, but almost immediately caught on. And how Hollywood portrayed autism, both wonderfully and not as well as could be. There were many misdiagnosis, misconceptions, the embracing and the pushing away. This is just a wonderful book, not just about autism itself, but the people within its sphere. The stories they want to tell and have the world understand.A very definite recommend.

GAB I received a free copy of this very interesting read from Goodreads, authors John Donvan and Caren Zucker, and Penguin RandomHouse, Crown Publishing Group in exchange for an honest review. Thank you all, for sharing your work with me.I found the sheer size of this history of autism daunting - but was a hundred and twenty pages in before I refilled my coffee cup. Written in a clear, easy-going style and with heart, before you know it your are caught up in the struggle for recognition and understanding of this fast growing, diverse spectrum of individual patterning we now know as autism. Though there are many historical instances of spectrum-like behavior as far back as written history goes, the first actual diagnosis of "autistic disturbances of affective contact" was made by Dr. Leo Kanner in September of 1942. Institutionalization was the only recommended procedure that followed that diagnosis. It was not until 1966 that the medical community actually admitted that autism in children was NOT caused by their 'refrigerator' mother's coldness and neglect. The general public still at times finds fault with the parenting of these children as a cause of autism. Some physicians, journalists, educators, lawyers and politicians eventually fell in step to support the strong, committed parents who struggled so long to receive equality in education and medical support for their children, but it was the 1990's before much was accomplished to insure help for these families, and clear uncaring Moms and vaccinations of children against viral illnesses - measles, polio, smallpox, rubella, mumps, etc - as an autism cause. This is an excellent history of autism, and a must read for educators, medical personnel, and family and friends of the autistic.

It's not entirely fair that I review this book without having reviewed NeuroTribes, a book with which it will inevitably be compared. I will have to leave it with saying that I greatly enjoyed NeuroTribes and it was one of my top books of 2015.While In a Different Key has enjoyed positive reviews from the mainstream press, it's been received less enthusiastically by neurodiversity advocates, with one going so far as to title her review "I read [it] so you don't have to." I think that goes too far. While there is troubling language in this book (for example, readers are invited to sympathize with a father who killed his autistic son), the book adds to the history of autism. It does primarily focus on the families and researchers, and less (until the end of the book, and the initial chapters on Donald Triplett) the voices of those who are themselves autistic. As a definitive history, this is a flaw, but a great deal of the history is still enlightening and interesting. The approach is more of a survey than NeuroTribes, which focused more intensely on fewer topics. Some of the sins of tone are borne of a desire for "balance" and sympathy, even when this is not necessarily appropriate to the topic. I would recommend tht people interested in the history of autism read both these books. NeuroTribes is more compelling as a story of autism, but In a Different Key fills in many gaps in people and chronology. The books also offer distinctly different characterizations of Hans Asperger, and readers may wish to decide for themselves.

I had the opportunity to read an Advanced Readers Copy of this book and absolutely loved it. It is a big book and could appear daunting given the topic and science involved, but the authors treat the subject matter like a narrative non-fiction, giving way to a compelling and easy read, despite the length of the book. The timeline at the very back of the book was helpful as the book isn't structured in a strict chronological order, but that was clearly done as a means of helping the narrative flow. I'd highly recommend this for anyone with even an inkling of interest in learning more about autism, although parents of children who are autistic might find some of the earlier "treatments" difficult to read about. The later chapters dealing with the anti-vaccine movement were handled in a sensitive manner that still managed to respect the beliefs of the anti-vaxxers. My only criticism is that often the writers employed a variation on the deus ex machina technique. What I mean is, it would be at a point in the story when some Big Thing in the history of autism was about to happen and suddenly the last line of a section would be akin to "And then So-and-So entered the picture and everything changed." It happened frequently and while I can appreciate there are only so many available methods for introducing new "characters" like that, I found it a bit tedious after awhile.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book. This book was unlike any other book I have read on the topic of autism. When I first got this book and saw how long it was, I was a but nervous that it would be a very technical dense read, but it was completely readable. As someone living life on the spectrum I learned new information. Many books I read are just a rehash of what I already know. But this was a complete historical account on Autism up the the present day. For example I was never aware that LSD was tested on children, and only vaguely understood the vaccination debate, as well as now understanding where the naming of Asperger's came from. These were some of the many new topics for me. Even if you are familiar with Autism, I think everyone could learn something from this book. In particular what I thought set this book apart from many others written on the topic were the accounts written by parents of their children growing up with disorders, whether they were in institutions or not. The personal stories were wonderful to have been included and shared. I feel that for me this added a lot. Had these not been included, while extremely detailed the book would not have been the same for me. In most other cases books are solely based on the authors experiences. It was lovely being able to follow the journey of Donald Triplett introduced at the beginning of the book as well as others.
